div.head: The Oppre≈ø≈øor de≈øtroyed.

epigraph.q: 119. P≈øal. 134. Deliver mee from the oppre≈øsion of man, ≈øo will I keep thy precepts, &c.

div.p: THere are two great troublers of our peace, & hinderers of our keeping the precepts of God, The fir≈øt is, violence of corruption within; the ≈øecond is, oppre≈ø≈øion without, In the ver≈øe before the Text, David prayeth for help again≈øt the former hinderance, namely, the violence of corruption within, Let not any iniquitie have dominion over mee, hee prayeth for help again≈øt the latter in the words now read, Deliver mee from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øo will I keep thy precepts.
Fir≈øt, Wee have here Davids prayer for deliverance, Deliver mee from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, oppre≈ø≈øion is the matter of it.
Secondly, Wee have Davids engagement, or his vow upon ≈øuppo≈øal of an an≈øwer to his prayers, So will I keep thy precepts.

Deliver mee, that is, redeem, re≈øcue me, oppre≈ø≈øion is bondage, deliverance from oppre≈ø≈øion is freedome, great deliverance hath Chri≈øt obtained for us, deliverance from ≈øinne, and deliverance from Hell, and this goeth under the name of redemption from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man; that is, from the oppre≈ø≈øion that man hath brought upon mee, or from oppre≈ø≈øing man; oppre≈ø≈øion in general is any wrong done to man by man: But more di≈øtinct, oppre≈ø≈øion may be con≈øidered, either in reference to the manner, or the matter of oppre≈ø≈øing, in reference to the manner, when it is violently and openly done, when men come boldly and oppre≈ø≈øe us. It is ≈øaid of Nymrod, that hee was a mighty Hunter before the Lord, hee was a Hunter of Bea≈øts, but more e≈øpecially a Hunter of men, Oppre≈ø≈øion in Scripture is often compared to hunting, in regard of the fiercene≈ø≈øe of it.

Secondly, There are ≈øecret and cunning oppre≈ø≈øions which the Prophet Ho≈øen ≈øpeakes of in the 12th of that Prophe≈øie, 7. ver≈øe, ≈øaith hee, hee is a Merchant, the ballance of deceipt is in his hand, hee loveth to oppre≈ø≈øe, who was this? ≈øaith hee, hee is a Merchant. As ≈øome oppre≈ø≈øe with a ≈øword in their hands, that is, violently and openly, come deliver up your e≈øtates or libertie, or deliver up your life? ≈øo is it with a paire of ballances in the hand. Ballances are put in a Synechdoche, for all the commerce betwixt man and man, now ≈øaith hee, here is one
that oppre≈ø≈øeth with Ballances in his hand; he tels you you ≈øhall have penny for penny, bargain for bargain: yet, ≈øaith he, he is an oppre≈ø≈øor, he loves to oppre≈ø≈øe.

Thirdly, You may di≈øtingui≈øh of Oppre≈ø≈øion, in regard of the matter of it, thus: in the fir≈øt place, Po≈øitive oppre≈ø≈øion, as in taking away from a man that which is his: ≈øecondly, Negative oppre≈ø≈øion, in with-holding that from a man which of right belongs unto him: Thou ≈øhalt not oppre≈ø≈øe the hyred ≈øervant, thou ≈øhalt pay him his wages at the day, &c. Deut. 24. 14. Againe, you may con≈øider Oppre≈ø≈øion, in regard of the matter of it, and ≈øo it is two-fold: fir≈øt, there is Civill oppre≈ø≈øion; ≈øecondly, there is Spirituall oppre≈ø≈øion.

Fir≈øt, Civill oppre≈ø≈øion is, when the matter is in civill things; and you may divide it either to oppre≈ø≈øion of our e≈øtate, or oppre≈ø≈øion of our per≈øons, Nehemiah 9. 37. The Kings that thou ha≈øt ≈øet over us for our ≈øinnes, have dominion over us: What dominion is this? It was a dominion over their per≈øons, and over their e≈øtates, at their will.

Secondly, There is Spirituall oppre≈ø≈øion, and that is of the Con≈øcience, when there are things impo≈øed upon the Con≈øcience, which God hath not made; tho≈øe things which are of mans making, to impo≈øe upon Con≈øcience. Thus the Scribes and Phari≈øes were great oppre≈ø≈øors, they oppre≈ø≈øed mens ≈øpirits, they did bind heavie burthens, and layd them upon mens ≈øhoulders, but they them≈øelves would not touch them with their little finger. Thus Antichri≈øt is the great Oppre≈ø≈øor, and hence the Seat of Antichri≈øt
hath three Names given it in Scripture, Sodom, Egypt, and Babylon: and here David prayeth, to be delivered from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man.

So will I keepe thy Precepts: I will doe it. He ≈øpeaks re≈øolutely, and yet he did not depend upon his own ≈øtrength. What is our ≈øtrength and our will? Alas, it is nothing: but wee may ≈øay ≈øo, as wee are under a Covenant of Grace, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from God, So will I keepe. The word which wee render here, to keepe, it ≈øignifieth to keepe a thing ≈øo, as to yeeld to it, obey it, and ≈øubmit to it: ≈øecondly, it ≈øignifieth to keepe a thing ≈øo, as to maintaine it, or protect it. I will keepe thy Precepts, ≈øaith David; that is, I will ≈øubmit to them, and obey them: or thus, I will keepe them, I will maintaine them, I will pre≈øerve them. So it is u≈øed, P≈øal. 116. 2. The Lord pre≈øerves the ≈øimple, or, he keepes the ≈øimple: Hee doth not meane by the ≈øimple, the man that is a foole, that hath no wi≈ødome or under≈øtanding; but the ≈øimple man, is a man of a ≈øimple heart, that hath no windings or doublings in his ≈øpirit: this is the man that is under the protection of the Lord. So it may be taken both wayes. By Precepts wee mu≈øt under≈øtand the whole revealed will of God, not onely Precepts of working, but Precepts of beleeving, it comprehends all: There are Precepts concerning things to be done, and Precepts concerning things to be beleeved: tho≈øe Precepts which are to be done, are ≈øuch as wee mu≈øt u≈øe in our ordinarie conver≈øation, the≈øe are Precepts of Holine≈ø≈øe; and then there are Precepts of Truth, in reference to Doctrine, what wee are to beleeve.
Object. But, may ≈øome ≈øay, did not David keepe the Precepts of God before?

I an≈øwer, Yes: David had kept the Precepts of God before; for the Lord ≈øpeakes of him as a man after his owne heart, who would fulfill all his will. What then is the meaning of this expre≈ø≈øion, Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man? The meaning is this; Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øo ≈øhall I have a better opportunitie to keepe thy Precepts. There are two great hinderances of the ≈øervice of God, as you have heard before, ≈øinne within, and oppre≈ø≈øion of man without. Againe, he meanes, I will keepe them more then I have done before; I will not live as formerly I have done: I have walked in the wayes of thy Commandements before, but now I will runne: This is the meaning of that expre≈ø≈øion, Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øo will I keepe thy Precepts.
Object. 2. But, may ≈øome ≈øay, if God would not deliver David, would not he keepe his Precepts?

For an≈øwer to this: David did not indent with God, and ≈øay, if God would not deliver him, then he would not keepe his Precepts; this was farre from Davids thoughts. Thus much for the explication of the Text, Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øo will I keepe thy Precepts.
There are ≈øeverall Ob≈øervations that ari≈øe from the words.

Doct. 1. Ob≈øerve, that in all Ages there hath bin among men, oppre≈ø≈øors of men: David found oppre≈ø≈øion in his time; yea, oppre≈ø≈øion was much elder
then David, it is as old as the World: as ≈øoone as there could be oppre≈ø≈øion, oppre≈ø≈øion appeared, Cain oppre≈ø≈øed Abel: in the Age after the Floud, there you reade of great oppre≈ø≈øion; Nimrod was a mightie Hunter before the Lord, he was the Patron of oppre≈ø≈øors, Gen. 10. 89. There is a notable oppre≈ø≈øion upon Record, Ier. which ≈øtands to this day again≈øt Jeru≈øalem, a Citie of God, a place where the people of God did dwell, and yet you ≈øhall finde oppre≈ø≈øion there, yea, nothing but oppre≈ø≈øion; ≈øhee is wholly oppre≈ø≈øed, ≈øome render it; Tota ip≈øa, ≈øhee is all oppre≈ø≈øed; and ≈øaith the Text, Oppre≈ø≈øion is in the mid≈øt of her, in interiori: it is not here to be meant locally, as if oppre≈ø≈øion were onely in the mid≈øt of the Citie; but in the mid≈øt of her as there is a middle in her heart, in her ≈øoule; oppre≈ø≈øion in her very ≈øpirits. As there is a ≈øpirit in man which lu≈øteth to envie, Iames 4. 5. ≈øo there is a ≈øpirit in man which lu≈øteth to oppre≈ø≈øe. An envious ≈øpirit is angry, troubled, and vexed, when any man enjoyeth any thing that is good. An oppre≈ø≈øing ≈øpirit will not give over oppre≈ø≈øing, till it hath taken away that good which a man doth enjoy. And in this, ≈øee how man is departed from the example of God: God, he is a pre≈øerver of man, a lover of man; and ≈øo ≈øhould man be to man: but they are as the Devill is to man, a De≈øtroyer, and an Oppre≈ø≈øor: Thus are many men to men.

Doct. 2. Ob≈øerve, (from the Text) Deliver me (≈øaith David) from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man. Man hath a very heavie hand upon man: David de≈øired rather
to be under the hand of God, then under the hand of man. The oppre≈ø≈øion of man is a very heavie oppre≈ø≈øion, David prayeth again≈øt it with all his might: the oppre≈ø≈øion of man is very heavie; it was that which made the P≈øalmi≈øt crie out: Ari≈øe, O God, to judge the fatherle≈ø≈øe and the oppre≈ø≈øed, that the men of the world may no more oppre≈ø≈øe; the word in the originall ≈øignifieth, to terrifie. Oppre≈ø≈øion in Scripture is expre≈ø≈øed by Deva≈øtation, it is that which layeth all wa≈øte; Oppre≈ø≈øion makes a wi≈øe man mad: Oppre≈ø≈øion doth not onely ≈øpoyle a man of his outward e≈øtate, but it even bereaveth him of his wits; he is as it were di≈øtracted, di≈ø-compo≈øed, unfit for to doe God ≈øervice. There are three phra≈øes given to Oppre≈ø≈øion, in Scripture:
Fir≈øt, The Scripture calleth Oppre≈ø≈øion the burthening of the people; which is very tedious.
Secondly, The Scripture calleth Oppre≈ø≈øion the grinding of the face; and that's farre wor≈øe.
Thirdly, The Scripture calleth Oppre≈ø≈øion the eating of the fle≈øh, the gnawing of the very bones; and that is wor≈øt of all.

Doct. 3. Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man: David was under a feare of oppre≈ø≈øion, and therefore he addre≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe to God: ob≈øerve, it is God alone that delivereth from oppre≈ø≈øion, he can doe it, he alone hath power to doe it, he will doe it, he hath promi≈øed to doe it, the glory of God con≈øi≈øts in it; he will doe it, for he is honoured by it; he will break the teeth of the oppre≈ø≈øors: The Lord doth this many wayes, but I will onely name three.
Fir≈øt, By the totall de≈øtruction and overthrow of Oppre≈ø≈øors, They ≈øhall be con≈øumed as ≈øtubble that is fully drie.

Secondly, The Lord delivereth his people from oppre≈ø≈øion, by re≈øtraining the rage and malice of the Enemie, that they are not able to hurt them; Hee ≈øuffered no man to doe them any wrong, ≈øaith the Text: This implyeth, that many would have done them wrong, but God put a barre upon their power, hee ≈øuffered no man to doe them any wrong. God kept the fire from burning the three Children: How? Not by putting out the fire, but by re≈øtraining the naturall power of the fire, that it could not burne them, Dan. 3. 23. God al≈øo pre≈øerved Daniel in the Lyons Denne: How? Not by de≈øtroying the Lyons, but by taking away the Lyons appetite, hee ≈øtayed their hunger, that they did not hurt Daniel, Dan. 6. 20.

Thirdly, Hee delivereth his from Oppre≈ø≈øion, by changing the hearts of their Oppre≈ø≈øors, hee can make them of Enemies to become friends, E≈øay 11. 6. The Wolfe al≈øo ≈øhall dwell with the Lamb, the Leopard ≈øhall lye downe with the Kid, and the Calfe and the young Lyon and the fatling together. God can ≈øo change the Lyon, that it ≈øhall not hurt the Lamb; hee can ≈øo alter the Leopard, that it ≈øhall not hurt the Kid, but both ≈øhall lye downe together, and the Earth ≈øhall be full of the knowledge of the Lord. Wee have had great experience of the Lords delivering us from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man: the fir≈øt way, by de≈øtroying all our oppre≈ø≈øors; yea, and by the ≈øecond way, when
our Enemies were ≈øtrong, hee hath re≈øtrained their power, that they were not able to hurt us. Now our la≈øt prayer for our Enemies ≈øhould be this, That God would change their hearts, that of Wolves they might become Lambs.
Doct. 4. The la≈øt Doctrine is this, That the Deliverance from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øhould be a ≈øtrong Engagement upon us, to a new and vigorous ≈øervice of God: So will I keepe thy Precepts.

Judgements call from ≈øinne, Amos 4. 10. I have brought this and evill upon you, ≈øaith the Lord, yet ye have not returned unto me: But the Voyce of Deliverance is e≈øpecially to call to Holine≈ø≈øe, and that for the≈øe following Rea≈øons.
Fir≈øt, Becau≈øe Deliverances are Mercies, and therefore they have this Obligation lying upon them.
Secondly, Deliverance from Oppre≈ø≈øion are great Mercies, and therefore it calls for more Holine≈ø≈øe.
Thirdly, Wee are under the Engagements of the Lord; wee have prayed for Deliverance, and behold the Lord hath now delivered us.

Fourthly, By Deliverance from our Enemies, we are freed from Incumbrances, and all Hinderances are taken away. Now wee have roome to ≈øerve God, now wee have an opportunitie to keepe Gods Precepts, now the Oppre≈ø≈øors are taken away; the enlarging of the heart is an inward helpe for the running of the wayes of thy Commandements.
I might give you many more Rea≈øons for the proofe of the Point, but I will winde up all in ≈øome few words of Application.

p.hi: Deliver me from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man, ≈øo will I keepe thy Precepts.

div.p:
Right Honourable, and well-beloved, I need not tell you, that wee are a people who have formerly groaned under Oppre≈ø≈øion, under ≈øuch as would have Dominion over our Bodies, over our Cattell, over our E≈øtates, at their plea≈øure, and e≈øpecially from them which would lay heavie Yokes upon our Spirits and Con≈øciences. I need not tell you, that wee have had ≈øuch Oppre≈ø≈øors, that ≈øurely the noy≈øe of tho≈øe that groaned under them, are not gone out of our eares. Againe, I need not tell you, that wee were lately under a feare, of having Oppre≈ø≈øion renewed upon us, and to have had tho≈øe to Rule over us, who≈øe little finger would have beene heavier then our former Oppre≈ø≈øors Loynes. I need not tell you of an Enemie that came like an over-flowing Floud, that would even have ≈øwallowed us up quick. I need not tell you, that wee are delivered from the≈øe mens oppre≈ø≈øions. I need not tell you, that wee have beene fearefully and wonderfully delivered; that there is not onely Mercie, but Miracle in our Deliverance. How hath the Oppre≈ø≈øor cea≈øed? They are cea≈øed (ble≈ø≈øed be God) but wee can ≈øcarcely ≈øay how. I hope I need not tell you, that it is God that hath delivered us from the oppre≈ø≈øion of man; though God hath made u≈øe of many worthy In≈øtruments, for the accompli≈øhing this
great Worke, which de≈øerve your chiefe≈øt commendations. I need not tell you of the≈øe things, ≈øuppo≈øing al≈øo that you will heare further concerning this particular at another time. The Deliverance that wee have now had from the oppre≈øsion of man, hath layd a mightie Engagement upon us to keepe Gods Precepts; it hath put an Engagement upon us, to keepe a Day of Pray≈øe and Thank≈ø-giving unto God; it hath put an Engagement upon us, to keepe his Precepts every day.

Fir≈øt, ≈øome may ≈øay, True it is, wee are delivered from the oppre≈øsion of man, our Enemies are de≈øtroyed: but, doe they ≈øay now, Come, let us keepe the Precepts of God? No, they are farre from that: Come, ≈øay they, now wee ≈øhall keepe our E≈øtates, and adde unto them; now our Trade is open, let us buy and ≈øell, and get Gaines; Though this in it ≈øelfe be lawfull, yet this is not the chiefe end that the people of God make of their Victories. Davids Re≈øolution was, Come, let us keepe the Precepts of God.

Secondly, There are others that ≈øay, Wee are delivered from the oppre≈øsion of man, Come, let us eate and drinke, and rejoyce, wee ≈øhall not dye to morrow; wee ≈øhall now live, our Enemies are downe, wee now ≈øeeme to have a longer terme added to our lives: ≈øurely, may ≈øome ≈øay, the bitterne≈ø≈øe of Death is gone.
